name: Kotor
fun_fact: Fun fact: Njegu코ki pr코ut (prosciutto) from the mountain village of Njegu코i above Kotor takes almost a year to produce. The pigs are slaughtered in November, the legs are salted and brined for 15 days, then smoked in a smokehouse with a fire tended around the clock for four months. What makes it legendary is the unique combination of salty Adriatic sea air and cool mountain breezes during the drying process.

hero_dishes.name: Njegu코ki Pr코ut (Njegu코i Prosciutto)
hero_dishes.description: Air-dried, smoked ham with unique flavor from the combination of salty sea air and mountain breezes during the year-long production process
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originating in the limestone Lov캖en mountains village of Njegu코i, high above Kotor. The climate creates perfect conditions for curing. The fire in the smokehouse is tended 24/7 for four months. This centuries-old tradition produces Montenegro's most famous delicacy.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Kod Pera na Bukovicu (Montenegro's oldest restaurant near Serpentine Road, family-run with on-site curing), Konoba Scala Santa (oldest restaurant in Kotor, opened 1931), Konoba Portun (artisanal cheese and cured meat platters)

hero_dishes.name: Crni Ri쬺t (Black Risotto)
hero_dishes.description: Seafood risotto with distinctive black color from squid ink, made with squid, mussels, clams, or shrimp, slowly cooked to absorb the rich briny essence
hero_dishes.origin_story: Venetian roots from Italy's medieval rule over the Adriatic coast. Popular along Montenegro and Croatia's coastline. The squid ink creates dramatic color and deep seafood flavor.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Cesarica (family-run by local fisherman with daily fresh catch from the bay), coastal restaurants in Kotor Old Town

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Adriatic Seafood
hero_dishes.description: Grilled or cooked sea bass, mackerel, bream, octopus, mussels, and squid - freshly caught and much-celebrated stars of coastal Montenegrin gastronomy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Montenegro's Adriatic coast provides daily fresh catches. Traditional preparation emphasizes the quality of fresh ingredients with simple grilling or stewing in olive oil.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Cesarica (fisherman-owned, unparalleled freshness, candlelit dinners, mussels and squid particularly tasty), Konoba Scala Santa (fish soup and fish stew are beloved), Konoba Portun (platform on the bay, grilled octopus and Adriatic fish)

hero_dishes.name: Njegu코ki Steak
hero_dishes.description: Veal schnitzel stuffed with Njegu코ki prosciutto and cheese - Montenegro's award-winning fusion dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created by Milovan Stojanovic, Tito's (Yugoslavia's President) personal chef. Won gold medal at the 1986 Culinary World Cup in Luxembourg. Combines the region's famous prosciutto with Austrian schnitzel tradition.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants in Kotor region, Kod Pera na Bukovicu (Njegu코i region)

signature_drinks.name: Rakija
signature_drinks.description: Montenegro's national drink - potent fruit brandy made from grapes, used for everything from weddings to funerals to curing the common cold
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Smokehouses tours in Njegu코i conclude with rakija shots. Used for toasting meals and celebrations. Locals believe it has medicinal properties. Served at room temperature in small glasses.

signature_drinks.name: Vranac (Red Wine)
signature_drinks.description: Autochthonous (native) red grape varietal producing Montenegro's signature red wines
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with hearty meat dishes and slow-cooked lamb. Part of long, relaxed Montenegrin dinners between 7-9pm where conversation and grazing over food and wine are encouraged.

signature_drinks.description: Krsta캜 is native white wine varietal. Nik코i캖ko is Montenegro's most popular pale lager beer
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Krsta캜 pairs with fresh seafood. Nik코i캖ko beer is commonly consumed with casual meals and at taverns (konobes).

food_culture_notes: Montenegro's cuisine blends coastal Mediterranean flavors with hearty mountain fare
Dinner time is usually between 7-9pm; coastal resorts like Kotor have restaurants open late in summer
Long, hearty lunches and dinners are encouraged - relaxing and enjoying conversation while grazing
Konobes (local taverns) represent authentic Montenegrin dining culture
Kotor City Market (between Sea and Southern gates) is the place to find fresh local ingredients
Get off the beaten path to avoid tourist traps - local spots sell out by mid-afternoon
Fresh seafood is the star of coastal cuisine, while Njegu코i region specializes in cured meats
Staples throughout Montenegro: 캜evapi (grilled minced meat sausages), ka캜amak (cornmeal and cheese mash)

Historic buildings converted to atmospheric taverns
Farm-to-table with on-site curing at mountain restaurants
